elements.content: In this work, we prepared two types of isostructural Ln3+-based metal–organic frameworks (LnMOFs) under solvothermal conditions, where two structurally similar pyridine-containing dicarboxylate ligands, 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)­nicotinic acid and [2,2′-bipyridine]-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid, were used as the organic linkers. The as-synthesized LnMOF compounds were characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), powder XRD, and thermogravimetric analysis. With the lanthanide co-doping approach, two mixed LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, were obtained and evaluated for application as potential ratiometric luminescence thermometers. The temperature-dependent luminescence of the two materials was investigated, and their emission intensities, luminescence lifetimes, and thermometric parameters were compared. They exhibit an excellent S-shaped response for temperatures in the range of 25–300 K, with favorable relative sensitivity and temperature uncertainty. Moreover, their color changes from green at 25 K to red at 300 K, so that they are also suitable as colorimetric luminescent probes.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we prepared two types of isostructural Ln3+-based metal-organic frameworks (LnMOFs) under solvothermal conditions, where two structurally similar pyridine-containing dicarboxylate ligands, 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)nicotinic acid and [2,2'-bipyridine]-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid, were used as the organic linkers. The as-synthesized LnMOF compounds were characterized using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (XRD), powder XRD, and thermogravimetric analysis. With the lanthanide co-doping approach, two mixed LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, were obtained and evaluated for application as potential ratiometric luminescence thermometers. The temperature-dependent luminescence of the two materials was investigated, and their emission intensities, luminescence lifetimes, and thermometric parameters were compared. They exhibit an excellent S-shaped response for temperatures in the range of 25-300 K, with favorable relative sensitivity and temperature uncertainty. Moreover, their color changes from green at 25 K to red at 300 K, so that they are also suitable as colorimetric luminescent probes.

elements.content: Two types of isostructural Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped metal−organic frameworks engineered from two different ligands were developed. Their thermometric parameters feature an excellent S-shaped response for temperatures in the range of 25−300 K.
elements.clean_text: Two types of isostructural Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped metal-organic frameworks engineered from two different ligands were developed. Their thermometric parameters feature an excellent S-shaped response for temperatures in the range of 25-300 K.

elements.content: The accurate measurement of temperature is of great importance in many fields of natural science, medicine, and technology. To date, many thermometers or sensors, such as liquid-filled glass and bimetallic thermometers, RTDs, thermocouples, and thermistors, have been developed to measure temperature. However, such traditional sensors have several weaknesses, such as their invasiveness, large size, use of electrical modules, need for direct contact with the measuring object, etc., so that they are not applicable for fast-evolving and/or submicrometer objects or strong electromagnetic fields. To overcome these limitations, much work has been devoted to noncontact thermometers, including luminescence-based temperature sensors, and much progress has been made. The dual-emitting ratiometric sensor, based on the intensity ratio of two easily distinguishable transition peaks, is one of the most promising. It does not need contact with the object, is self-calibrating and highly accurate, has a fast response and an excellent resolution (at the submicrometer level), and is applicable under most electromagnetic conditions. Although ratiometric thermometers can be based on organic molecule compounds, polymer dots, chelate complexes, upconversion nanoparticles, etc., Ln3+-based metal–organic frameworks (LnMOFs) have attracted attention because of their unique luminescent properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The accurate measurement of temperature is of great importance in many fields of natural science, medicine, and technology. To date, many thermometers or sensors, such as liquid-filled glass and bimetallic thermometers, RTDs, thermocouples, and thermistors, have been developed to measure temperature. However, such traditional sensors have several weaknesses, such as their invasiveness, large size, use of electrical modules, need for direct contact with the measuring object, etc., so that they are not applicable for fast-evolving and/or submicrometer objects or strong electromagnetic fields. To overcome these limitations, much work has been devoted to noncontact thermometers, including luminescence-based temperature sensors, and much progress has been made. The dual-emitting ratiometric sensor, based on the intensity ratio of two easily distinguishable transition peaks, is one of the most promising. It does not need contact with the object, is self-calibrating and highly accurate, has a fast response and an excellent resolution (at the submicrometer level), and is applicable under most electromagnetic conditions. Although ratiometric thermometers can be based on organic molecule compounds, polymer dots, chelate complexes, upconversion nanoparticles, etc., Ln3+-based metal-organic frameworks (LnMOFs) have attracted attention because of their unique luminescent properties.

elements.content: LnMOFs, self-assembled from lanthanide-containing nodes or clusters with organic ligands, are versatile and stable luminescent emitters with high emission quantum yields. They combine the spectroscopic properties of lanthanides (e.g., long fluorescence lifetime, wide emission range, and well-defined narrow band) with the unique advantages of MOFs such as diverse structures, permanent porosity, and outstanding designability. They have thus attracted a great deal of attention in the past few years and opened a new direction for developing novel luminescent sensory materials. By taking advantage of the thermally sensitive properties of lanthanide ions, Chen, Qian, and co-workers introduced the first ratiometric luminescent mixed LnMOF (M′LnMOF) thermal probe based on the intensity ratio of the 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+, 545 nm) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+, 613 nm) transitions. Later, bimetallic LnMOF thermometers for different temperature regimes, including cryogenic (T < 100 K), medium (T = 100–300 K), physiological (T = 293–323 K), and high (T > 373 K) temperatures, were introduced. The key point of the LnMOF system is their sensitive temperature dependence of energy transfer and back transfer probabilities between the ligands, the lanthanide ions, e.g., Tb3+ and Eu3+. The temperature dependence of the latter’s luminescence is mainly determined by the energy transfer process, including ligand-to-Tb3+ and ligand-to-Eu3+ transfer as well as Tb3+-to-Eu3+ transfer. However, the temperature-dependent properties of M′LnMOFs with an identical structure, engineered from different ligands, have not been investigated in detail or compared.
elements.clean_text: LnMOFs, self-assembled from lanthanide-containing nodes or clusters with organic ligands, are versatile and stable luminescent emitters with high emission quantum yields. They combine the spectroscopic properties of lanthanides (e.g., long fluorescence lifetime, wide emission range, and well-defined narrow band) with the unique advantages of MOFs such as diverse structures, permanent porosity, and outstanding designability. They have thus attracted a great deal of attention in the past few years and opened a new direction for developing novel luminescent sensory materials. By taking advantage of the thermally sensitive properties of lanthanide ions, Chen, Qian, and co-workers introduced the first ratiometric luminescent mixed LnMOF (M'LnMOF) thermal probe based on the intensity ratio of the 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+, 545 nm) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+, 613 nm) transitions. Later, bimetallic LnMOF thermometers for different temperature regimes, including cryogenic (T < 100 K), medium (T = 100-300 K), physiological (T = 293-323 K), and high (T > 373 K) temperatures, were introduced. The key point of the LnMOF system is their sensitive temperature dependence of energy transfer and back transfer probabilities between the ligands, the lanthanide ions, e.g., Tb3+ and Eu3+. The temperature dependence of the latter's luminescence is mainly determined by the energy transfer process, including ligand-to-Tb3+ and ligand-to-Eu3+ transfer as well as Tb3+-to-Eu3+ transfer. However, the temperature-dependent properties of M'LnMOFs with an identical structure, engineered from different ligands, have not been investigated in detail or compared.

elements.content: In this work, we use 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)­nicotinic acid (H2cpna) and [2,2′-bipyridine]-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpydc) with carboxylate and pyridine moieties as linkers () to fabricate the LnMOFs with Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. Different numbers of pyridine units in the ligand can give rise to different lowest triplet state energies and affect the sensitization of the ligand to Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. In addition, the two ligands have similar spatial geometry and stereohindrance and can be expected to generate isostructural LnMOFs. With the lanthanide ion co-doping strategy, we successfully prepared two new isostructural M′LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, with the same synthesis procedure. The temperature dependence of photoluminescence intensities and thermometric parameters for these two isostructural M′LnMOFs is investigated and explained in terms of the generalized Mott–Seitz model. Our results show that their ratiometric parameters feature an excellent S-shaped response to temperature in the range of 25–300 K, with favorable relative sensitivities and low temperature uncertainties. The temperature dependence of energy transfer from the Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions in the two samples is also evaluated.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we use 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)nicotinic acid (H2cpna) and [2,2'-bipyridine]-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid (H2bpydc) with carboxylate and pyridine moieties as linkers () to fabricate the LnMOFs with Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. Different numbers of pyridine units in the ligand can give rise to different lowest triplet state energies and affect the sensitization of the ligand to Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. In addition, the two ligands have similar spatial geometry and stereohindrance and can be expected to generate isostructural LnMOFs. With the lanthanide ion co-doping strategy, we successfully prepared two new isostructural M'LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, with the same synthesis procedure. The temperature dependence of photoluminescence intensities and thermometric parameters for these two isostructural M'LnMOFs is investigated and explained in terms of the generalized Mott-Seitz model. Our results show that their ratiometric parameters feature an excellent S-shaped response to temperature in the range of 25-300 K, with favorable relative sensitivities and low temperature uncertainties. The temperature dependence of energy transfer from the Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions in the two samples is also evaluated.

elements.clean_text: 1  Organic Ligands H2cpna and H2bpydc Used To Construct the Isostructural M'LnMOFs

elements.content: The ligands H2cpna and H2bpydc used in this work were obtained from Ji’nan Henghua Co. All other chemicals and materials were commercially available and used without additional purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the MOF samples were obtained on a MAXima_X XRD-7000 diffraction instrument equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation and recorded in the 2θ range of 5–50° under room conditions. The size and morphology of the crystals were characterized using an Olympus IX73 inverted microscope. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted on a Netzsch TG209F3 analyzer under a continuous nitrogen flow from 35 to 800 °C (heating rate of 5 °C/min). An EA1112 microelemental analyzer was used to conduct the elemental analyses (C, H, and N) of the compounds. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy was performed on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP spectrometer. The photoluminescence spectra of the powder LnMOFs were obtained on an Edinburgh Instrument F920 spectrometer, and the temperature was controlled by a closed-cycle He cryostat equipped with a Lakeshore temperature controller. The quantum yields of the LnMOFs were measured using a BaSO4-coated integrating sphere and calculated through an absolute method. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of Eucpna were performed on a Bruke Smart Apex II diffractometer (Mo X-ray source, Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) equipped with an Atlas detector at 296 K. Bruker SAINT was applied to collect and process the diffraction data for Eucpna. Its crystal structure was determined by direct methods and refined using SHELX-2013 on the basis of the full-matrix least-squares method. All non-hydrogen atoms were located exactly and refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were generated at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. Table S1 lists the crystallographic data for Eucpna.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

The ligands H2cpna and H2bpydc used in this work were obtained from Ji'nan Henghua Co. All other chemicals and materials were commercially available and used without additional purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the MOF samples were obtained on a MAXima_X XRD-7000 diffraction instrument equipped with Cu Kα (λ = 1.542 Å) radiation and recorded in the 2θ range of 5-50° under room conditions. The size and morphology of the crystals were characterized using an Olympus IX73 inverted microscope. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was conducted on a Netzsch TG209F3 analyzer under a continuous nitrogen flow from 35 to 800 °C (heating rate of 5 °C/min). An EA1112 microelemental analyzer was used to conduct the elemental analyses (C, H, and N) of the compounds. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy was performed on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP spectrometer. The photoluminescence spectra of the powder LnMOFs were obtained on an Edinburgh Instrument F920 spectrometer, and the temperature was controlled by a closed-cycle He cryostat equipped with a Lakeshore temperature controller. The quantum yields of the LnMOFs were measured using a BaSO4-coated integrating sphere and calculated through an absolute method. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements of Eucpna were performed on a Bruke Smart Apex II diffractometer (Mo X-ray source, Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) equipped with an Atlas detector at 296 K. Bruker SAINT was applied to collect and process the diffraction data for Eucpna. Its crystal structure was determined by direct methods and refined using SHELX-2013 on the basis of the full-matrix least-squares method. All non-hydrogen atoms were located exactly and refined anisotropically, and the hydrogen atoms were generated at calculated positions and refined by using a riding mode. Table S1 lists the crystallographic data for Eucpna.

elements.content: With Eucpna as an example, H2cpna (20 mg, 0.082 mmol), Eu­(NO3)2·6H2O (40 mg, 0.088 mmol), dimethylacetamide (1 mL), chlorobenzene (1 mL), and methylbenzene (0.2 mL) were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon vessel with a stainless steel housing and heated at 115 °C for 3 days. The resulting blocklike crystals of Eucpna were collected by filtration with filter paper and washed with DMA and ethanol several times, giving a yield of 67%. Anal. Calcd for [Eu2(cpna)3(DMA)2]·(H2O)9: C, 40.47; H, 3.40; N, 5.02. Found: C, 40.93; H, 3.324; N, 5.06. The Tbcpna and Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOF Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna were synthesized in a manner similar to that of Eucpna, except that Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O and a mixture of Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O and Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O were used as the starting lanthanide salts, respectively. Moreover, the same synthetic procedures using the ligand H2bpydc can be applied to prepare Eubpydc, Tbbpydc, and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of LnMOFs and M'LnMOFs (Ln = Eu3+ or Tb3+)

With Eucpna as an example, H2cpna (20 mg, 0.082 mmol), Eu(NO3)2⋅6H2O (40 mg, 0.088 mmol), dimethylacetamide (1 mL), chlorobenzene (1 mL), and methylbenzene (0.2 mL) were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon vessel with a stainless steel housing and heated at 115 °C for 3 days. The resulting blocklike crystals of Eucpna were collected by filtration with filter paper and washed with DMA and ethanol several times, giving a yield of 67%. Anal. Calcd for [Eu2(cpna)3(DMA)2]⋅(H2O)9: C, 40.47; H, 3.40; N, 5.02. Found: C, 40.93; H, 3.324; N, 5.06. The Tbcpna and Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOF Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna were synthesized in a manner similar to that of Eucpna, except that Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O and a mixture of Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O and Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O were used as the starting lanthanide salts, respectively. Moreover, the same synthetic procedures using the ligand H2bpydc can be applied to prepare Eubpydc, Tbbpydc, and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc.

elements.content: Solvothermal reactions of Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O and H2cpna in mixed solvents of dimethylacetamide (DMA), chlorobenzene, and methylbenzene at 115 °C for 3 days yield blocklike crystals of [Eu2(cpna)3(DMA)2]·(H2O)9(Eucpna). The formula of Eucpna was confirmed by single-crystal XRD, TG, and element studies. Single-crystal XRD reveals that the asymmetric unit of Eucpna contains two Eu atoms, three cpna ligands, and two DMA molecules and crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group (Table S1). As shown in a, the Eu3+ ion coordinates to six carboxylic oxygen atoms from six different cpna ligands and one DMA molecule, and the coordination polyhedron around the Eu3+ ion can be described as a slightly distorted bicapped trigonal prism. The Eu–O (carboxylic) bond lengths range from 2.320(6) to 2.351(6) Å, similar to the averages reported for Eu-containing MOFs. Neighboring Eu3+ ions, at a spatial distance of 4.7220(7) Å, are linked by three carboxylic oxygen atoms of three cpna ligands to form a right-handed helical chain along the crystallographic b-axis (b). The infinite europium–carboxylate chains are bridged in a parallel manner with each other by the cpna ligands to construct a three-dimensional (3D) framework, which exhibits two groups of interpenetrated and perpendicular one-dimensional (1D) rhombic channels along the a- and b-axis directions (c). As expected, replacement of the organic ligand H2cpna with a structurally similar H2bpydc in the same reaction process yielded the analogous MOF, Eubpydc. The shapes of as-obtained Encpna and Eubpydc were observed via inverted optical microscopy (Figure S1). Additionally, the M′LnMOFs Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc can be obtained by using an identical synthesis procedure except that the mixture of Tb­(NO3)3 and Eu­(NO3)3 was used as the lanthanide source. The Tb3+:Eu3+ molar ratios in the as-obtained M′LnMOF samples were characterized by ICP measurement and correspond to the initial inputs of each salt in the mixture (Table S2). Powder XRD of the as-synthesized MOFs shows that all of the samples are isostructural to the simulated pattern of Eucpna, despite the fact that H2bpydc-based LnMOF samples were prepared using a linking ligand containing two pyridine rings (Figure S2). Matching large-angle diffraction peaks beyond 2θ values of 25° are presented for all as-synthesized products, confirming the phase purity and highly crystalline structure for these lanthanide MOFs. The TG curves of Eucpna and Eubpydc show the two molecules in the channel (Figure S3); the second step with a 11.73% weight loss (calcd, 11.79%) in the range from 125 to 285 °C is attributed to the loss of two coordinated DMA molecules, after which the decomposition takes place to give the desolvated framework after further heating to 500 °C. Therefore, both Eucpna and Eubpydc have good thermostability: the main crystal structure of Eucpna is thermally stable up to 500 °C, while Eubpydc up to 460 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Solvothermal reactions of Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O and H2cpna in mixed solvents of dimethylacetamide (DMA), chlorobenzene, and methylbenzene at 115 °C for 3 days yield blocklike crystals of [Eu2(cpna)3(DMA)2]⋅(H2O)9(Eucpna). The formula of Eucpna was confirmed by single-crystal XRD, TG, and element studies. Single-crystal XRD reveals that the asymmetric unit of Eucpna contains two Eu atoms, three cpna ligands, and two DMA molecules and crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group (Table S1). As shown in a, the Eu3+ ion coordinates to six carboxylic oxygen atoms from six different cpna ligands and one DMA molecule, and the coordination polyhedron around the Eu3+ ion can be described as a slightly distorted bicapped trigonal prism. The Eu-O (carboxylic) bond lengths range from 2.320(6) to 2.351(6) Å, similar to the averages reported for Eu-containing MOFs. Neighboring Eu3+ ions, at a spatial distance of 4.7220(7) Å, are linked by three carboxylic oxygen atoms of three cpna ligands to form a right-handed helical chain along the crystallographic b-axis (b). The infinite europium-carboxylate chains are bridged in a parallel manner with each other by the cpna ligands to construct a three-dimensional (3D) framework, which exhibits two groups of interpenetrated and perpendicular one-dimensional (1D) rhombic channels along the a- and b-axis directions (c). As expected, replacement of the organic ligand H2cpna with a structurally similar H2bpydc in the same reaction process yielded the analogous MOF, Eubpydc. The shapes of as-obtained Encpna and Eubpydc were observed via inverted optical microscopy (Figure S1). Additionally, the M'LnMOFs Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc can be obtained by using an identical synthesis procedure except that the mixture of Tb(NO3)3 and Eu(NO3)3 was used as the lanthanide source. The Tb3+:Eu3+ molar ratios in the as-obtained M'LnMOF samples were characterized by ICP measurement and correspond to the initial inputs of each salt in the mixture (Table S2). Powder XRD of the as-synthesized MOFs shows that all of the samples are isostructural to the simulated pattern of Eucpna, despite the fact that H2bpydc-based LnMOF samples were prepared using a linking ligand containing two pyridine rings (Figure S2). Matching large-angle diffraction peaks beyond 2θ values of 25° are presented for all as-synthesized products, confirming the phase purity and highly crystalline structure for these lanthanide MOFs. The TG curves of Eucpna and Eubpydc show the two molecules in the channel (Figure S3); the second step with a 11.73% weight loss (calcd, 11.79%) in the range from 125 to 285 °C is attributed to the loss of two coordinated DMA molecules, after which the decomposition takes place to give the desolvated framework after further heating to 500 °C. Therefore, both Eucpna and Eubpydc have good thermostability: the main crystal structure of Eucpna is thermally stable up to 500 °C, while Eubpydc up to 460 °C.

elements.content: (a) View of the local coordination environment of Eu3+ with a slightly distorted bicapped trigonal prismatic configuration. (b) 1D infinite Eu3+–carboxylate helical chain along the b-axis. (c) Two groups of interpenetrated and perpendicular 1D rhombic channels along the a- and b-axis directions. Legend: Eu, blue; C, gray; O, red; N, blue. For the sake of clarity, H atoms and solvent molecules have been omitted.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) View of the local coordination environment of Eu3+ with a slightly distorted bicapped trigonal prismatic configuration. (b) 1D infinite Eu3+-carboxylate helical chain along the b-axis. (c) Two groups of interpenetrated and perpendicular 1D rhombic channels along the a- and b-axis directions. Legend: Eu, blue; C, gray; O, red; N, blue. For the sake of clarity, H atoms and solvent molecules have been omitted.

elements.content: The emission and excitation spectra of the powder samples of H2cpna and H2bpydc ligands and those of Lncpna and Lnbpydc were recorded under room conditions (Figures S4–S6). As shown in Figure S4, the H2cpna and H2bpydc ligands can be excited to fluoresce under the given ultraviolet (UV) light due to the intermolecular π–π* and n−π* transitions of organic ligands. Under excitation at 328 nm, Tbcpna and Eucpna exhibit the typical Tb3+ and Eu3+ characteristic emission peaks, respectively. Tbcpna shows typical emission around 488, 544, 587, and 621 nm, corresponding to the 5D4 → 7F6–3 (Tb3+) transitions (Figure S5a), while Eucpna displays strong peaks at 578, 592, 612, 652, and 700 nm, which are assigned to 5D0 → 7F0–4 (Eu3+) transitions (Figure S5b). Similarly, for excitation at 339 nm, Tbbpydc and Eubpydc also display the typical Tb3+ and Eu3+ emission peaks, respectively, consistent with those of the Tbcpna and Eucpna (Figure S6). Interestingly, the emissions of the free ligands, H2cpna and H2bpydc, completely disappear in their corresponding LnMOFs, indicating that both H2cpna and H2bpydc are excellent chromophores for sensitization of both Tb3+ and Eu3+ luminescence. However, we should mention that these two ligands with different numbers of pyridine moieties would have different distributions of triplet energy states and be strongly associated with the sensitization efficiency for Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. Specifically, the quantum yield of Tbbpydc under room conditions is determined to be 8.29% (Table S3), which is more than 2 times that of Tbcpna (3.13%). Clearly, H2bpydc has stronger sensitization for Tb3+ ions compared to that of H2cpna, which can be further confirmed by the temperature dependence of luminescence analysis.
elements.clean_text: The emission and excitation spectra of the powder samples of H2cpna and H2bpydc ligands and those of Lncpna and Lnbpydc were recorded under room conditions (Figures S4-S6). As shown in Figure S4, the H2cpna and H2bpydc ligands can be excited to fluoresce under the given ultraviolet (UV) light due to the intermolecular π-π* and n-π* transitions of organic ligands. Under excitation at 328 nm, Tbcpna and Eucpna exhibit the typical Tb3+ and Eu3+ characteristic emission peaks, respectively. Tbcpna shows typical emission around 488, 544, 587, and 621 nm, corresponding to the 5D4 → 7F6-3 (Tb3+) transitions (Figure S5a), while Eucpna displays strong peaks at 578, 592, 612, 652, and 700 nm, which are assigned to 5D0 → 7F0-4 (Eu3+) transitions (Figure S5b). Similarly, for excitation at 339 nm, Tbbpydc and Eubpydc also display the typical Tb3+ and Eu3+ emission peaks, respectively, consistent with those of the Tbcpna and Eucpna (Figure S6). Interestingly, the emissions of the free ligands, H2cpna and H2bpydc, completely disappear in their corresponding LnMOFs, indicating that both H2cpna and H2bpydc are excellent chromophores for sensitization of both Tb3+ and Eu3+ luminescence. However, we should mention that these two ligands with different numbers of pyridine moieties would have different distributions of triplet energy states and be strongly associated with the sensitization efficiency for Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. Specifically, the quantum yield of Tbbpydc under room conditions is determined to be 8.29% (Table S3), which is more than 2 times that of Tbcpna (3.13%). Clearly, H2bpydc has stronger sensitization for Tb3+ ions compared to that of H2cpna, which can be further confirmed by the temperature dependence of luminescence analysis.

elements.content: As depicted in a, at 25 K, the emission intensity of Tb3+ (544 nm, 5D4 → 7F5) of Tbcpna is very strong and then decreases by 0.38% K–1 with temperature, whereas at 150 K, the intensity at 544 nm is quenched by more than half. This temperature-response behavior of luminescence is significantly different from that of Tbbpydc (b), whose Tb3+ emission intensity is nearly unchanged in the temperature range of 25–150 K and then dramatically decreases by 0.55% K–1 with temperature up to 300 K. In addition, the fluorescence lifetimes of 5D4 for Tbcpna and Tbbpydc also exhibit the same variation trend as their corresponding emission intensities (Figure S7). Further insight into the mechanism of sensitization of the ligand to Tb3+ ions is provided by the temperature dependence of the intensity (I) at 544 nm, which is well-described by the equation I = I 0 1 + α exp ( − Δ E / K B T ) where I 0 is the emission intensity of Tb3+ (544 nm) at 0 K, T the absolute temperature, α the ratio between nonradiative and radiative rates, ΔE the activation energy of the thermal quenching process of Tb3+ luminescence at 544 nm, and K B Boltzmann’s constant. The red solid lines in panels c and d of are the temperature calibration curves for Tbcpna and Tbbpydc, respectively, determined by fitting the intensity points to , giving activation energies of 368.34 cm–1 for Tbcpna (ΔE a) and 965.08 cm–1 for Tbbpydc (ΔE b). The remaining fitted parameters are summarized in Table S4. The obtained activation energy of the nonradiative channel involves energy transfer between the 5D4 level of Tb3+ ions and the ligand triplet level. Compared to Tbcpna, the temperature-sensitive range of Tbbpydc is significantly elevated to the range of 150–300 K, which can be attributed to the higher activation energy of the deactivation channel between H2bpydc and Tb3+ that can effectively decrease the thermal quenching and mixed-decay transitions at cryogenic temperatures. Additionally, the luminescence of Eu3+ of both Eucpna and Eubpydc is not sensitive to temperature, as shown in Figures S8 and S9, respectively.
elements.clean_text: As depicted in a, at 25 K, the emission intensity of Tb3+ (544 nm, 5D4 → 7F5) of Tbcpna is very strong and then decreases by 0.38% K-1 with temperature, whereas at 150 K, the intensity at 544 nm is quenched by more than half. This temperature-response behavior of luminescence is significantly different from that of Tbbpydc (b), whose Tb3+ emission intensity is nearly unchanged in the temperature range of 25-150 K and then dramatically decreases by 0.55% K-1 with temperature up to 300 K. In addition, the fluorescence lifetimes of 5D4 for Tbcpna and Tbbpydc also exhibit the same variation trend as their corresponding emission intensities (Figure S7). Further insight into the mechanism of sensitization of the ligand to Tb3+ ions is provided by the temperature dependence of the intensity (I) at 544 nm, which is well-described by the equation  1     I =     I   0     1 + α  exp  ( - Δ E /   K   B   T )       where I 0 is the emission intensity of Tb3+ (544 nm) at 0 K, T the absolute temperature, α the ratio between nonradiative and radiative rates, ΔE the activation energy of the thermal quenching process of Tb3+ luminescence at 544 nm, and K B Boltzmann's constant. The red solid lines in panels c and d of  are the temperature calibration curves for Tbcpna and Tbbpydc, respectively, determined by fitting the intensity points to , giving activation energies of 368.34 cm-1 for Tbcpna (ΔE a) and 965.08 cm-1 for Tbbpydc (ΔE b). The remaining fitted parameters are summarized in Table S4. The obtained activation energy of the nonradiative channel involves energy transfer between the 5D4 level of Tb3+ ions and the ligand triplet level. Compared to Tbcpna, the temperature-sensitive range of Tbbpydc is significantly elevated to the range of 150-300 K, which can be attributed to the higher activation energy of the deactivation channel between H2bpydc and Tb3+ that can effectively decrease the thermal quenching and mixed-decay transitions at cryogenic temperatures. Additionally, the luminescence of Eu3+ of both Eucpna and Eubpydc is not sensitive to temperature, as shown in Figures S8 and S9, respectively.

elements.content: Emission spectra of (a) Tbcpna and (b) Tbbpydc recorded in the range of 25–300 K. Temperature-dependent peak intensity (green) and best fit calibration curve (red) of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition for (c) Tbcpna and (d) Tbbpydc.
elements.clean_text: 2  Emission spectra of (a) Tbcpna and (b) Tbbpydc recorded in the range of 25-300 K. Temperature-dependent peak intensity (green) and best fit calibration curve (red) of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition for (c) Tbcpna and (d) Tbbpydc.

elements.content: The different luminescence behavior of Tb3+ ions in Tbcpna and Tbbpydc motivated us to incorporate a very small number of Eu3+ ions into their frameworks to realize the Tb/Eu co-doped MOFs as the ratiometeric thermometers for the cryogenic regime. As shown in Figure S10, doped M′LnMOFs Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc simultaneously display the characteristic luminescence of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions under UV light excitation at room temperature. It must be mentioned that although the doped amount of Eu3+ is far smaller than that of Tb3+ in each sample, the emission intensity of Eu3+ is in a dominate position over their corresponding spectra. The is not only due to the efficient energy transfer from ligands to Eu3+ ions but also due to the fact that the luminescence of Eu3+ ions in the Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOFs is further sensitized by the Tb3+ ions within the identical framework.
elements.clean_text: The different luminescence behavior of Tb3+ ions in Tbcpna and Tbbpydc motivated us to incorporate a very small number of Eu3+ ions into their frameworks to realize the Tb/Eu co-doped MOFs as the ratiometeric thermometers for the cryogenic regime. As shown in Figure S10, doped M'LnMOFs Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc simultaneously display the characteristic luminescence of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions under UV light excitation at room temperature. It must be mentioned that although the doped amount of Eu3+ is far smaller than that of Tb3+ in each sample, the emission intensity of Eu3+ is in a dominate position over their corresponding spectra. The is not only due to the efficient energy transfer from ligands to Eu3+ ions but also due to the fact that the luminescence of Eu3+ ions in the Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOFs is further sensitized by the Tb3+ ions within the identical framework.

elements.content: The temperature-dependent luminescence spectra of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc between 25 and 300 K were recorded to evaluate their potential applications as ratiometric luminescent thermometers. As illustrated in panels a and b of , both Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc exhibit significantly different temperature-dependent luminescence behavior with respect to the emission peaks of Tb3+ at 544 nm and Eu3+ at 612 nm. From the emission spectrum of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna (a and Figure S11a), we can see that the peak intensity of Tb3+ decreased by 0.45% K–1 with an increase in temperature from 25 to 150 K, while the emission of Eu3+ is significantly enhanced. As mentioned, Tbcpna delivers a much lower decreased rate (0.38% K–1) for Tb3+ emission intensity, and Eucpna is not sensitive to temperature. Thus, a significant enhancement of the Eu3+ emission within Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna is a typical process for energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions, which is based on the thermally driven phonon-assisted energy transfer mechanism. Similar behavior was observed in the isostructural Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, but it exhibits different extents of change in the corresponding emissions (b and Figure S11b). Accordingly, the intensity ratios (Δ = I Tb/I Eu) of the Tb3+ and Eu3+ emissions for Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc show different temperature dependence.
elements.clean_text: The temperature-dependent luminescence spectra of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc between 25 and 300 K were recorded to evaluate their potential applications as ratiometric luminescent thermometers. As illustrated in panels a and b of , both Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc exhibit significantly different temperature-dependent luminescence behavior with respect to the emission peaks of Tb3+ at 544 nm and Eu3+ at 612 nm. From the emission spectrum of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna (a and Figure S11a), we can see that the peak intensity of Tb3+ decreased by 0.45% K-1 with an increase in temperature from 25 to 150 K, while the emission of Eu3+ is significantly enhanced. As mentioned, Tbcpna delivers a much lower decreased rate (0.38% K-1) for Tb3+ emission intensity, and Eucpna is not sensitive to temperature. Thus, a significant enhancement of the Eu3+ emission within Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna is a typical process for energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions, which is based on the thermally driven phonon-assisted energy transfer mechanism. Similar behavior was observed in the isostructural Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, but it exhibits different extents of change in the corresponding emissions (b and Figure S11b). Accordingly, the intensity ratios (Δ = I Tb/I Eu) of the Tb3+ and Eu3+ emissions for Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc show different temperature dependence.

elements.content: Emission spectra of (a) Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and (b) Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc recorded between 25 and 300 K.
elements.clean_text: 3  Emission spectra of (a) Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and (b) Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc recorded between 25 and 300 K.

elements.content: In theory, the temperature-dependent intensity ratio Δ of most Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOFs can be rationalized on the basis of the generalized Mott–Seitz model that considered the competition between the radiative transition and nonradiative decay of each luminescence center. Given the fact that the quenching of Tb3+ emission is the dominant deactivation effect in the cryogenic regime (a,b), the relationships between the ratiometric parameter Δ and the temperature T of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc can be determined by Δ = Δ 0 1 + α 1 exp ( − Δ E 1 / K B T ) + α 2 exp ( − Δ E 2 / K B T ) where Δ0 is the initial ratiometric parameter (T = 0 K), α1 and α2 are the ratios between nonradiative (T = 0 K) and radiative rates of the deactivation channels for the Tb3+ center, ΔE 1 and ΔE 2 are the activation energies for the nonradiative channels, and K B is Boltzmann’s constant. The TeSen-tool can be applied to determine the thermometric parameters in our Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOF systems. As shown in a, the experimental values of intensity ratio Δ for Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are well fitted by , giving a ΔE 1a of 519.93 cm–1 and a ΔE 2a of 86.59 cm–1 for Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and a ΔE 1b of 854.22 cm–1 and a ΔE 2b of 119.73 cm–1 for Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc. The rest of fitted parameters are listed in Table S4. The fit R 2 values for the experimental data points of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are 0.9997 and 0.9989, respectively, suggesting the validity of , which provides two deactivation recombination channels in our M′LnMOFs. The blue and red solid lines derived by the Mott–Seitz model demonstrate the nature of the two thermally activated nonradiative channels of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, respectively. The larger fitted deactivation energy involves the nonradiative deactivation between the 5D4 level of Tb3+ and the ligand triplet level, while the smaller energy ΔE 2 most likely involves the energy transfer between the Tb3+ 5D4 level and the Eu3+ 5D2 level.
elements.clean_text: In theory, the temperature-dependent intensity ratio Δ of most Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOFs can be rationalized on the basis of the generalized Mott-Seitz model that considered the competition between the radiative transition and nonradiative decay of each luminescence center. Given the fact that the quenching of Tb3+ emission is the dominant deactivation effect in the cryogenic regime (a,b), the relationships between the ratiometric parameter Δ and the temperature T of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc can be determined by      Δ =     Δ   0     1 +   α   1   exp  ( - Δ   E   1   /   K   B   T )  +   α   2   exp  ( - Δ   E   2   /   K   B   T )       2 where Δ0 is the initial ratiometric parameter (T = 0 K), α1 and α2 are the ratios between nonradiative (T = 0 K) and radiative rates of the deactivation channels for the Tb3+ center, ΔE 1 and ΔE 2 are the activation energies for the nonradiative channels, and K B is Boltzmann's constant. The TeSen-tool can be applied to determine the thermometric parameters in our Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOF systems. As shown in a, the experimental values of intensity ratio Δ for Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are well fitted by , giving a ΔE 1a of 519.93 cm-1 and a ΔE 2a of 86.59 cm-1 for Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and a ΔE 1b of 854.22 cm-1 and a ΔE 2b of 119.73 cm-1 for Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc. The rest of fitted parameters are listed in Table S4. The fit R 2 values for the experimental data points of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are 0.9997 and 0.9989, respectively, suggesting the validity of , which provides two deactivation recombination channels in our M'LnMOFs. The blue and red solid lines derived by the Mott-Seitz model demonstrate the nature of the two thermally activated nonradiative channels of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, respectively. The larger fitted deactivation energy involves the nonradiative deactivation between the 5D4 level of Tb3+ and the ligand triplet level, while the smaller energy ΔE 2 most likely involves the energy transfer between the Tb3+ 5D4 level and the Eu3+ 5D2 level.

elements.content: (a) Blue and red symbols depict the values of experimental thermometric parameter Δ of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna, respectively, and the solid lines present the best fit of the experimental values using eq . (b) Relative sensitivity of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc in the range of 25–300 K. (c) Corresponding temperature uncertainty of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) Blue and red symbols depict the values of experimental thermometric parameter Δ of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna, respectively, and the solid lines present the best fit of the experimental values using eq  . (b) Relative sensitivity of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc in the range of 25-300 K. (c) Corresponding temperature uncertainty of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc.

elements.content: In general, the Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer efficiency (ηET) in the M′LnMOFs can be calculated via the equation η ET = 1 − τ 1 τ 0 where τ1 and τ0 are the lifetimes of the 5D4 transition of the Tb3+ donor in the presence and absence of the Eu3+ acceptors, respectively. Figure S12 shows the ηET values of Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc in the operating temperature range along with the ηET values of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna for comparison. In the cryogenic regime, the ηET values of the two samples are weak and then increase at different rates as the temperature increases. At 225 K, the ηET of Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc is 77.6%, which is much higher than that of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna (49.6%). The remarkable improvement in ηET for Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc with an increase in temperature can be attributed to the enhanced thermally driven phonon-assisted energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions as well as the efficient antenna effect of the ligand H2bpydc.
elements.clean_text: In general, the Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer efficiency (ηET) in the M'LnMOFs can be calculated via the equation  3       η   ET   = 1 -     τ   1       τ   0        where τ1 and τ0 are the lifetimes of the 5D4 transition of the Tb3+ donor in the presence and absence of the Eu3+ acceptors, respectively. Figure S12 shows the ηET values of Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc in the operating temperature range along with the ηET values of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna for comparison. In the cryogenic regime, the ηET values of the two samples are weak and then increase at different rates as the temperature increases. At 225 K, the ηET of Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc is 77.6%, which is much higher than that of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna (49.6%). The remarkable improvement in ηET for Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc with an increase in temperature can be attributed to the enhanced thermally driven phonon-assisted energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions as well as the efficient antenna effect of the ligand H2bpydc.

elements.content: The relative sensitivity S r, as a figure of merit of self-calibrated luminescence thermometry, is commonly used to evaluate the performance of fluorescence thermometers and can be defined as S r = ∂ Δ / ∂ T Δ where Δ is the ratiometric parameter and T is the given temperature. As shown in b, the maximum relative sensitivity of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna is determined to be 2.55% K–1 at 131 K, while that of Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc is 2.59% K–1 at 179 K. The temperature uncertainty δT is another index for assessing the thermometer performance and can be determined by δ T = δ Δ / Δ S r where δΔ/Δ is the relative uncertainty of Δ. As the δΔ/Δ of common fluorescence detectors, such as PMTs and CCDs, can reach a typical value of 0.02%, the minimum temperature uncertainties of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are estimated to be 0.02 K (at 131 K) and 0.01 K (at 179 K), respectively (c). In addition, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are sensitive luminescent colorimetric probes. The emission color change of these two MOFs with an increase in temperature is depicted on the Commission International d’Eclairage (CIE) color diagram in , and the corresponding x and y coordinates for each temperature are listed in Table S5. As displayed in , the emission colors of both Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc change from green (25 K) to red (300 K) upon heating, which can be easily observed by the digital cameras and the naked eye. The high relative sensitivities, low temperature uncertainties, and temperature-sensitive colors of the two Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOFs suggest that they are competitive luminescent thermometers covering the cryogenic regime.
elements.clean_text: The relative sensitivity S r, as a figure of merit of self-calibrated luminescence thermometry, is commonly used to evaluate the performance of fluorescence thermometers and can be defined as  4       S   r   =   ∂ Δ / ∂ T   Δ      where Δ is the ratiometric parameter and T is the given temperature. As shown in b, the maximum relative sensitivity of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna is determined to be 2.55% K-1 at 131 K, while that of Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc is 2.59% K-1 at 179 K. The temperature uncertainty δT is another index for assessing the thermometer performance and can be determined by  5     δ T =   δ Δ / Δ     S   r        where δΔ/Δ is the relative uncertainty of Δ. As the δΔ/Δ of common fluorescence detectors, such as PMTs and CCDs, can reach a typical value of 0.02%, the minimum temperature uncertainties of Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are estimated to be 0.02 K (at 131 K) and 0.01 K (at 179 K), respectively (c). In addition, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc are sensitive luminescent colorimetric probes. The emission color change of these two MOFs with an increase in temperature is depicted on the Commission International d'Eclairage (CIE) color diagram in , and the corresponding x and y coordinates for each temperature are listed in Table S5. As displayed in , the emission colors of both Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc change from green (25 K) to red (300 K) upon heating, which can be easily observed by the digital cameras and the naked eye. The high relative sensitivities, low temperature uncertainties, and temperature-sensitive colors of the two Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOFs suggest that they are competitive luminescent thermometers covering the cryogenic regime.

elements.content: CIE chromaticity diagram presenting the temperature-dependent color of (a) Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and (b) Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc changing from green at 25 K to red at 300 K.
elements.clean_text: 5  CIE chromaticity diagram presenting the temperature-dependent color of (a) Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and (b) Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc changing from green at 25 K to red at 300 K.

elements.content: In summary, two structurally similar pyridine-containing dicarboxylate ligands, 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)­nicotinic acid and [2,2′-bipyridine]-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid, were selected to construct the luminescent MOFs with Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. Interestingly, these two types of LnMOFs were prepared using the same synthesis approach and show identical crystal structures. The obtained LnMOF samples were characterized by single-crystal XRD, powder XRD, and TG studies. With the Eu3+/Tb3+ co-doping approach, two M′LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, effective in the temperature range of 25–300 K, were prepared and further evaluated as ratiometric luminescent temperature probes. It was observed that both of the two compounds gave promising luminescence responses for ratiometric temperature sensors; specifically, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna shows a maximum S r of 2.55% K–1 and a minimum δT of 0.02 K both at 131 K, while Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc presents a maximum S r of 2.59% K–1 and a minimum δT of 0.01 K both at 179 K. In addition, the thermally sensitive emission colors of these two M′LnMOFs highlight their potential use as colorimetric probes to directly visualize temperature distributions and variations by combining traditional imaging techniques.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two structurally similar pyridine-containing dicarboxylate ligands, 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)nicotinic acid and [2,2'-bipyridine]-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid, were selected to construct the luminescent MOFs with Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. Interestingly, these two types of LnMOFs were prepared using the same synthesis approach and show identical crystal structures. The obtained LnMOF samples were characterized by single-crystal XRD, powder XRD, and TG studies. With the Eu3+/Tb3+ co-doping approach, two M'LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, effective in the temperature range of 25-300 K, were prepared and further evaluated as ratiometric luminescent temperature probes. It was observed that both of the two compounds gave promising luminescence responses for ratiometric temperature sensors; specifically, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna shows a maximum S r of 2.55% K-1 and a minimum δT of 0.02 K both at 131 K, while Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc presents a maximum S r of 2.59% K-1 and a minimum δT of 0.01 K both at 179 K. In addition, the thermally sensitive emission colors of these two M'LnMOFs highlight their potential use as colorimetric probes to directly visualize temperature distributions and variations by combining traditional imaging techniques.

cln_elements.content: With Eucpna as an example, H2cpna (20 mg, 0.082 mmol), Eu­(NO3)2·6H2O (40 mg, 0.088 mmol), dimethylacetamide (1 mL), chlorobenzene (1 mL), and methylbenzene (0.2 mL) were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon vessel with a stainless steel housing and heated at 115 °C for 3 days. The resulting blocklike crystals of Eucpna were collected by filtration with filter paper and washed with DMA and ethanol several times, giving a yield of 67%. Anal. Calcd for [Eu2(cpna)3(DMA)2]·(H2O)9: C, 40.47; H, 3.40; N, 5.02. Found: C, 40.93; H, 3.324; N, 5.06. The Tbcpna and Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOF Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna were synthesized in a manner similar to that of Eucpna, except that Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O and a mixture of Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O and Eu­(NO3)3·6H2O were used as the starting lanthanide salts, respectively. Moreover, the same synthetic procedures using the ligand H2bpydc can be applied to prepare Eubpydc, Tbbpydc, and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of LnMOFs and M'LnMOFs (Ln = Eu3+ or Tb3+)

With Eucpna as an example, H2cpna (20 mg, 0.082 mmol), Eu(NO3)2⋅6H2O (40 mg, 0.088 mmol), dimethylacetamide (1 mL), chlorobenzene (1 mL), and methylbenzene (0.2 mL) were sealed in a 25 mL Teflon vessel with a stainless steel housing and heated at 115 °C for 3 days. The resulting blocklike crystals of Eucpna were collected by filtration with filter paper and washed with DMA and ethanol several times, giving a yield of 67%. Anal. Calcd for [Eu2(cpna)3(DMA)2]⋅(H2O)9: C, 40.47; H, 3.40; N, 5.02. Found: C, 40.93; H, 3.324; N, 5.06. The Tbcpna and Tb3+/Eu3+ co-doped MOF Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna were synthesized in a manner similar to that of Eucpna, except that Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O and a mixture of Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O and Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O were used as the starting lanthanide salts, respectively. Moreover, the same synthetic procedures using the ligand H2bpydc can be applied to prepare Eubpydc, Tbbpydc, and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc.

cln_elements.content: In summary, two structurally similar pyridine-containing dicarboxylate ligands, 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)­nicotinic acid and [2,2′-bipyridine]-5,5′-dicarboxylic acid, were selected to construct the luminescent MOFs with Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. Interestingly, these two types of LnMOFs were prepared using the same synthesis approach and show identical crystal structures. The obtained LnMOF samples were characterized by single-crystal XRD, powder XRD, and TG studies. With the Eu3+/Tb3+ co-doping approach, two M′LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, effective in the temperature range of 25–300 K, were prepared and further evaluated as ratiometric luminescent temperature probes. It was observed that both of the two compounds gave promising luminescence responses for ratiometric temperature sensors; specifically, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna shows a maximum S r of 2.55% K–1 and a minimum δT of 0.02 K both at 131 K, while Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc presents a maximum S r of 2.59% K–1 and a minimum δT of 0.01 K both at 179 K. In addition, the thermally sensitive emission colors of these two M′LnMOFs highlight their potential use as colorimetric probes to directly visualize temperature distributions and variations by combining traditional imaging techniques.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, two structurally similar pyridine-containing dicarboxylate ligands, 6-(4-carboxyphenyl)nicotinic acid and [2,2'-bipyridine]-5,5'-dicarboxylic acid, were selected to construct the luminescent MOFs with Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions. Interestingly, these two types of LnMOFs were prepared using the same synthesis approach and show identical crystal structures. The obtained LnMOF samples were characterized by single-crystal XRD, powder XRD, and TG studies. With the Eu3+/Tb3+ co-doping approach, two M'LnMOFs, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna and Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc, effective in the temperature range of 25-300 K, were prepared and further evaluated as ratiometric luminescent temperature probes. It was observed that both of the two compounds gave promising luminescence responses for ratiometric temperature sensors; specifically, Tb0.95Eu0.05cpna shows a maximum S r of 2.55% K-1 and a minimum δT of 0.02 K both at 131 K, while Tb0.95Eu0.05bpydc presents a maximum S r of 2.59% K-1 and a minimum δT of 0.01 K both at 179 K. In addition, the thermally sensitive emission colors of these two M'LnMOFs highlight their potential use as colorimetric probes to directly visualize temperature distributions and variations by combining traditional imaging techniques.

Isostructural Tb3+/Eu3+ Co-Doped
